Entry.1:
Staying Kedievial Hotel. Despatched three large photos of Pyramids – 1 to Dorrie, 1 Anne & Charlie, 1 to Ruby. Bought wristlet watch P.T. 100. "G. Lekegian, Photographer". 

Bought "Vest Kodak" double lense & cover P.T. 300. Day too cloudy for snapping. Left Cairo 6.15, arrived "Tel El Kebir" 9 p.m. after an enjoyable day in town.
Entry.2: Camp fatigues today. Nothing of importance going on. Windy and dusty. No Church Parade.
Entry.3: Appointed Sec. Clerk to purchase goods for Sec. Nothing of importance going. Heavy rain for about ½ hour.
Entry.4: Company busy improving camp. Nothing of importance going except that troops are still coming in.
Entry.5: Nothing unusual doing. Camp growing rapidly. Very windy & cold. I’m acting Sec. Clerk.
Entry.6: Everything going as usual. Still more troops pouring in. The camp is growing rapidly. Very windy & cool. Took Photo cemetery Tel El Kebir.
Entry.7: Usual camp routine, dull & fatigues. Nothing unusual happening. Windy & cloudy.
Entry.8: Light rain during most last night. Continued most today. Nothing unusual happening.
Entry.9: Beautiful weather today. Usual fatigues. No drill. Took several photos of camp, 3 Corps Engineers 125 Brigade Inf. & Artillery. Nothing fresh of importance.
Entry.10: Nothing of importance to relate. Some of Coy. Pontoon Bridging on Canal. Troops still coming in to Camp.
Entry.11: Working on Camp cooking ovens & other fatigues. Things going as usual. Troops coming in every day. Large numbers going down Canal.
Entry.12: Working on Cooking ovens. Half holiday. Nothing fresh going. Beautiful warm days. Cool nights.
Entry.13: Working on buildings today as Carpenters. Nothing fresh going. Troops still coming into Camp.
Entry.14: Pontooning Bridging in morning. Practising in the afternoon for big Review Parade tomorrow.
Entry.15: Pontooning in the forenoon. In the after. all troops were reviewed in afternoon by Gen. Murray.
Entry.16: Church Parade in forenoon. A little light fatigues otherwise nothing doing. Things going as usual.
Entry.17: Working in C.R.E. yards & on water troughs on Canal. Nothing of importance to report.
Entry.18: Working C.R.E. yard. Large numbers troops still going down Canal. Large number Camels.
Entry.19: Working in R.E. yard. Nothing fresh of importance going. Large number troops passing through each day.
Entry.20: Working R.E. yard. Usual Company routine. Transports & troops passing through daily.
Entry.21: Still working in R.E. yard. Beautiful weather. Nothing fresh going. Troops still passing through.
Entry.22: Exempt duty today sore feet. Promoted L.Cp. this morning.
Entry.23: Exempt duty. Harry came to see me today. Nothing fresh going. Attended Divine Service in Y.M.C.A. at night.
Entry.24: Exempt duty on account of having sore feet. No. 2 Coy. left Camp for presumably the Canal. Nothing else going of importance.
Entry.25: Cpl. of the Guard today. Very heavy wind, a little rain & very cold. Nothing of importance going.
Entry.26: Had easy day after coming off Guard. R.E. Engrs. occupied 2nd Coy’s old lines. Nothing importance.
Entry.27: Shifted from T.E.K. to * Advance party. Lft. Keast, Cpl. Dobbie, Cpl. Faine, Cpl. Murray. Was in charge baggage party. (Serapeum *)
Entry.28: Had lazy time today. Nothing doing. A lot of work going on here preparing for supposed attack coming. Caught in very heavy rain yesterday. Showers since.
Entry.29: Took charge "Pontoon" bridge today. Much stores & traffic crossing Canal.
Entry.30: Working "Pontoon" bridge on Canal. Great preparation going on for supposed coming attack. Nothing else of importance.
Entry.31: Working Pontoon bridge. Very windy making handling bridge very difficult.
Entry.32: Working bridge as usual. Nothing fresh reported. 7th, 8th Batts. crossed Canal today.
Entry.33: Working "Pontoon bridge". A great deal of traffic crossed today. Also much traffic on the Canal.
Entry.34: Windy today making work on Pontoon bridge very hard. Nothing of importance going that we have heard of.
Entry.35: Working on Pontoon bridge. Windy making work difficult. Not so much traffic as usual across Canal.
Entry.36: Very windy today, work on bridge being very hard. Heavy rain in evening & early last night.
Entry.37: Not much doing today. Took walk down Canal for about a mile in the morning to view scene of last years attack by the Turks.
Entry.38: Had easy day at work today. Nothing of importance going. Beautiful day. Working on "Pontoon bridge".
Entry.39: Usual work on Pontoon bridge. No news of importance going. A lot of shipping going through Canal.
Entry.40: Working on Pontoon bridge. Nothing of importance reported. Very heavy wind & a little rain. Wind made Bridge difficult to work.
Entry.41: Usual bridge work this fine day. Nothing of importance going.
Entry.42: Usual work on Pontoon bridge. Nothing out of the usual reported. Much preparation going on across the Canal. Very windy.
Entry.43: Working on Pontoon bridge as usual. Bridging Train to take over tomorrow.
Entry.44: Had holiday today. In morning walked to Toussom Signal Station. Bridging train took over bridge this morning. "Kiarra" thro’ today.
Entry.45: Took charge party twelve Saprs. to Rail Head about 8 miles from Canal to supervise receiving & stacking stores. Also issuing.
Entry.46: Supervising receiving & stacking stores at Rail Head. Large quantities coming in. Much work going on.
Entry.47:
Same work as 
usual
 yesterday. Large amount of stores still coming in. Remainder No. 1 Sec. now here.
Entry.48: Same work receiving stores. Sec. Officer. Mr. Keast took charge this afternoon. Country nothing but sandy waste.
Entry.49: Working in R.E. yard same as last few days. Nothing of importance reported. Hot & windy.
Entry.50: Very windy, warm & dusty. Usual working in R.E. yard.
Entry.51: Working in morning, had afternoon off. Usual R.E. yard work. Nothing of importance reported.
Entry.52:
Working R.E. yard.
 Working R.E. yard, nigger driving & supervising stacking timber.
Entry.53: R.E. yard work. Same as usual. Nothing fresh reported. Getting very warm.
Entry.54: Usual work in R.E. yard. Nothing of importance reported. Windy & dusty and very warm.
Entry.55: Usual R.E. yard work going on. Great activity Railway water scheme etc. Took snaps R.E. yard.
Entry.56: Working in R.E. yard same as usual lately. Nothing fresh reported.
Entry.57: Working in R.E. yard as usual, receiving & stacking stores.
Entry.58: On duty as usual in R.E. yard.
Entry.59: On duty in R.E. yard. Nothing to report.
Entry.60: R.E. yard. Reported Greece in war.
Entry.61: Working in R.E. yard. Reported another British boat sunk off Dover.
Entry.62: Tremendous heavy wind, dense dust lasting all day. Working in R.E. yard.
Entry.63: Same work as yesterday. Having terrific wind and dust.
Entry.64: Wind still very heavy. Nothing fresh to report.
Entry.65: Again windy & dusty. Went to Canal & had a swim. Usual R E yard work. Nothing fresh reported.
Entry.66: Working in R E yard as usual. Nothing fresh going. Expect to leave tomorrow.
Entry.67: Left R.E yard & reported to H.Q. to leave for new Coy. Had to stay here for day.
Entry.68: Still with Coy. waiting for orders to move. Nothing of importance reported.
Entry.69: Left Serapheum about 7 a.m., arrived at Tel El Kebir about 1 p.m. To be allotted new Coy. tomorrow.
Entry.70: Thirty-two F.F. Coy. allotted to 14th F. Coy. this morning. Took up position site near Camp. Waiting for Reinforcements.
Entry.71: Very little doing today. Waiting for
Entry.72: Easy day, morning parade & inspection. Nothing fresh doing.
Entry.73: Had party making tables. Easy times. Company not properly formed yet.
Entry.74: Cairo on leave. Visited Museum took several photos, gardens etc., nice day.
Entry.75: Usual camp fatigues. Nothing of importance going to note. Visited Chaplain Ward in evening.
Entry.76: Getting camp ready for in-coming men. Nothing of importance to note.
Entry.77: Things as usual. Getting camp ready for incoming draft.
Entry.78: Heavy wind. 160 men came into camp to form up new Coy.
Entry.79: Sections allotted Coy. Promoted to 1st Cpl. Oglivy & Banks promoted Sgts. Nothing else of importance going.
Entry.80: Was Orderly Corporal today. Company commenced training today. Nothing else importance.
Entry.81: Was out with Section in morning. Field geometry in morning & knotting & lashing in afternoon.
Entry.82: Carrying on training. Nothing of importance to note.
Entry.83: Had party on fatigues in morning. Innoculated in afternoon.
Entry.84: Had party 4 men in Cairo on duty to get kit bags, did not get them.
Entry.85: Instructing knotting & lashings. Issued clothing in afternoon.
Entry.86: Nothing special doing. Went to service in Y.M.C.A. hut at night with N. Monaghan speaker-Dr. Werner.
Entry.87: Rifle drill in morning. In afternoon on Canal Bridging weld on Trestle and and Pontoon.
Entry.88: Took party 6 men to Cairo to get kit bags. Had very good trip. Beautiful weather.
Entry.89: Started Route march to Ferry Post "Ismailia" 14th Brigade 14th, 15th Engrs. Very hot, many fell out.
Entry.90: Marched all day. Many fell out owing to great strain marching in heat over sand with full pack. Very little water!
Entry.91: Arrived Ferry Post noon. Troops very much fatigued. Marched about 40 miles, a good many collapsed on march.
Entry.92: Started work today. Boys still feeling effect of severe march.
Entry.93: Had charge Section for squad drill in morning. Camp fatigues in afternoon & swimming parade.
Entry.94: Rifle drill, squad drill & work about camp. Nothing of importance going reported.
Entry.95: Squad drill & work fixing up the Camp. Weather hot, rather trying for men drilling.
Entry.96: Drill & work on water supply. Nothing of importance going.
Entry.97: Out with part of Section teaching them revetting trenching.
Entry.98: Had Sec. out drilling also instructing in trench construction. Getting very hot.
Entry.99: Had section out drilling also in trenches & instructing in construction.
Entry.100: No drill for Sec. Was kept very busy most of the day preparing for work in trenches tomorrow.
Entry.101: Had party working in trenches, also Coy. of Infantry working revetting, etc.
Entry.102: Constructing trenches in Bridge Head defences about one mile from Ferry post.
Entry.103: Same as yesterday. Supervising trench construction by our own Sappers & Infantry.
Entry.104: Still working in trench revetting & instructing Infantry. Tremendous heavy wind.
Entry.105: Still windy. Heavy rain settling dust a great deal. Working revetting trenches.
Entry.106: Reported L. Horse had brush with party Turks off Serapheum capturing 40. One L.H. man killed.
Entry.107: Only morning Parade. No work in Trenches. Beautiful day tho’ very warm.
Entry.108: Work in trenches in morning. Handed over to No. 3 Section. Musketry in afternoon.
Entry.109:
Musketry – squad drill - 
trench work
. Nothing of importance reported.
Entry.110: Instructing Section in Musketry all day, training very hard. Nothing of importance reported.
Entry.111: Musketry all day again today. Weather very warm. Nothing of importance going.
Entry.112: Usual drill and Rifle exercises. Nothing of importance going.
Entry.113: Out with Section. Rifle exercises, squad drill & Demolition.
Entry.114: Very little doing today. Cpl. Furnell & I went to Ismailia in afternoon.
Entry.115: Nos. 1 & 2 Sections were out on Rifle Range for Musketry. Did fairly well.
Entry.116: Anzac Day. O.C. Inspected Coy. in morning, also gave lecture. Had rest day free.
Entry.117: Inspection by O.C. in morning. Inspected by Brgdr. McCay in afternoon.
Entry.118: Marched to Rifle Range in morning & had Musketry. Had extended order drill in afternoon.
Entry.119:
Rifle drill etc. in morning. In afternoon was Inspected by 
Gen. Goodley
 Col. Carey.
Entry.120: Drilling in morning. In afternoon was inspected by Gen. Goodley .
Entry.121: Our half Coy. from Canal Took over work from other half Coy. Supervising Divisional work, Hutting & all other work of camp.
Entry.122: In charge Hutting of Brgd. A great amount of work going on in camp – hutting, sanitation, etc.
Entry.123: Same as yesterday, Supervising Hutting & other work in camp. Nothing fresh going, things quiet.
Entry.124: Still working on Camp improvements, Hutting, water supply etc.
Entry.125: Same work as yesterday. Nothing fresh going.
Entry.126: Same work, Hutting, Sanitation, etc. Weather getting very hot. Nothing fresh going.
Entry.128: Very hot day. A lot of boys vaccinated. Had easy day.
Entry.129: Setting out Hutting, also supervising work.
Entry.130: Whole Company went to Rifle Range in morning and had Rifle practice. Lecture afterwards.
Entry.131: Had fairly easy time in Camp. Had short lecture on Demolition morning practically afternoon.
Entry.132: Went to Rifle Range in morning practically in morning – little Camp fatigue in afternoon.
Entry.133: Turned out 7 a.m. & took part in Divisional Battle movement.
Entry.134: Had charge work erecting Compound at Canteen – wet. Things quiet.
Entry.135: Very hot and dusty, got orders to pack up ready to go to Rail Head tomorrow. Y.M.C.A. night.
Entry.136: Left camp 5 a.m. & marched to Rail Head, about 7 miles distant. My Sec. No. 2 marched another 4 miles & took up duty.
Entry.137: Stationed "Duntroon". We are in charge work Hutting, water supply etc. at "Gundagai", "Katoomba", Mt. Kembla & Duntroon.
Entry.138: Extraordinary heat yesterday & today. Reported yesterday to 118° in shade in No. 2 Officers tent & today 125°.
Entry.139: Still very hot but not so hot as yesterday. Working on water reservoir & other camp work.
Entry.140: Heat wave has passed over and it is now much cooler. Working on water conservation scheme.
Entry.141: Same as yesterday. Nothing fresh reported.
Entry.142: Very little doing today. Had most of day off. Nothing of importance going.
Entry.143: Working on water tanks & Drinking troughs. Still nice and cool.
Entry.144: General work about camp – building – waterworks etc.
Entry.145: Nothing fresh going. Coy. still carrying out building – water works, work in trenches etc.
Entry.146: Same work as usual – building etc. Nothing fresh going. Still nice and cool.
Entry.147: Working on buildings, water supply etc. Nothing fresh going.
Entry.148: Work as usual on buildings, etc. Had Kit Inspection, expect to be going away.
Entry.149: Welsh R.Es came today to relieve us. Packed up ready to leave. Expect to leave tomorrow.
Entry.150: Marched to Rail Head today & from there on to "Ferry Post" where we’ll stay until going to Moaskar.
Entry.151: Traing in usual work today besides fixing up camp. Nothing fresh going.
Entry.153: Pontooning & bridging on "Suez Canal". Constructed bridge.
Entry.154: Demolition today. Fired all surplus "Training" gun cotton away.
Entry.155: Marched to Moaskar, distance about 6 miles.
Entry.156: Working on Camp all day. Weather very hot.
Entry.157: A little drill in morning. Pontooning in afternoon near Ismailia.
Entry.158: Working on Mess Hut in our Lines today. No. 1 & 3 Pontooning on Sweet Water Canal.
Entry.159: Working again today on Mess Hut. No. 1 & 3 Pontooning on Sweet Water Canal.
Entry.160: Word that Lord Kitchener was downed on Tuesday when H.M.S. Hampshire went down off Orkney Islands. Torpedoed or mined.
Entry.162: Pontooning on Sweet Water Canal in morning. Sports in afternoon.
Entry.163: Had easy day today. Only work on Camp fatigues.
Entry.164: Pontoon bridging on Sweet Water Canal. News of big Russian victories against Austrians.
Entry.165: Squad & Rifle Drill in morning. "Kitchener" Memorial Service in afternoon, also took charge Guards.
Entry.166: Had charge Guards today. Nothing fresh going. Expect to move before long.
Entry.167: Pontooning today on the Sweet Water Canal today.
Entry.168: Pontoon bridging, trestle forming and other bridging work. Very hot.
Entry.169: Left "Moaskar" at about 10 p.m. for Alexandria preparatory to Embarking for France.
Entry.170:
Arrived Alexandria about 6 a.m. & went aboard the Kinfauns" & remained in Harbor all day.

Monday 19 June 1916

Lying in Harbor all day. The "Georgina" with 14th &
Entry.171: F. Coy. Drivers & Horses aboard got away about 6.30 p.m.
Entry.172: Lying in Harbor all day. Weather very hot. Do not expect to leave for several days for some reason or other.
Entry.173: Lying in Harbor all day. A few Transports left. Yachting in Harbor in afternoon, very pretty.
Entry.174: Left Alexandria at about 10.30 a.m. Had very good trip during day. Sea nice & smooth.
Entry.175: Still making very good progress. Weather calm & cooler than in Egypt.
Entry.176: Said to have sighted submarine about noon. Still making good trip. Weather rather good.
Entry.177: Altered course for some reason about daybreak & ran into Malta, ship here all day.
Entry.178: Left Malta about 6.30 p.m. with "Caladonia" & 2 other Transports. Escorted by destroyers & cruiser.
Entry.179: Making good progress. Sighted African coast in morning. Travelling along Sardinian Coast in evening.
Entry.180: Made good passage. Arrived Marseilles about 8 p.m. Anchored in outer for the night.
Entry.181: Left Marseille port about 9 p.m. Left Kingfauns Castle about 3 p.m. Every thing going well.
Entry.182: Making good journey. Country extremely beautiful along the Valley on the Rhone from Mornas to Lyon, also right along.
Entry.183: Making good trip. Nice weather & everything looking beautiful.
Entry.184: Arrived Thiennes about 8 a.m. & marched 8 K. & took up billet in farm house. Good dry shelter, all troop billeted.
Entry.185: Camped at Atoin near town of Thiennes. Ulahns were here last year. British passed through, retreat Mons.
Entry.186: Heavy rain today. Having Gas Helmet drill & other drill, map reading etc. Reported good advance British.
Entry.187: First pay in France. Still very dull & showery. Nothing fresh going. Could hear heavy bombardment last night.
Entry.188: Had 10 mile route march in morning. Issued with Gas Helmets, goggles & Steel Helmets in afternoon.
Entry.189: Route march 10 miles in forenoon. Gas Helmet drill in afternoon.
Entry.190: Marched in all about 15 miles. Had Test in Gas with Gas Helmets only.
Entry.191: Started march to Firing line. Camped Estaires. Passed through Merville, fine town. All going well.
Entry.192: Left Estaires 0600, marched through Sailly to Fleurbaix & camped in an old convent – very much knocked about by Artillery fire.
Entry.193: Some of Coy started working trenches. Shifted into new Billets. Very little doing.
Entry.194: Went into new Billets today. Nothing of importance going. Had a look around.
Entry.195: No. 2 Section got 5 days leave, two large shells lobbed near billets. Things going quiet.
Entry.196: About 40 shells lobbed near Village & damaged Battery of Artillery. Took party into Bac St. Maur tonight to .
Entry.197: Very heavy bombardment by Germans. Fairly heavy casualties. Working day & night.
Entry.198: Heavy bombardment by our Guns. Heavy reply from Germans. We expect to charge tomorrow.
Entry.199: Did not attack German trenches today. Expect to do so tomorrow. Bombarding enemy line effectively.
Entry.200: Heavy bombardment of enemy line by our Artillery today. Did not attack. Making preparation to do so.
Entry.201: Attacked enemy position & advanced 900 yards No. 2 Sec. with 50 --- & consolidated position.
Entry.202: Enemy outflanked our new position & we had to retire into our old lines. Very heavy Enemy bombardment.
Entry.203: Worked last night revetting "Bromton Avenue". Company resting today. Casualties heavy in yesterday’s engagement.
Entry.204: Shifted Billet to Fleur Baix. Nothing fresh going. Things settling down.
Entry.205: Looking round firing line preparatory to taking over work here. Things very quiet here.
Entry.206: Started revetting communication trenches & repairing and building dugout in Firing line. Things going well.
Entry.207: Had charge party revetting in "Bay Avenue". Late in afternoon shells entered & did considerable damage.
Entry.208: Had Party Sappers & Infantry revetting Abbots Rd. morning & evening & right on through night. Little shelling.
Entry.209: In charge parties revetting Abbot Avenue. A good deal of shelling in parts Lines. Things going well.
Entry.210: Revetting Bay Avenue, other Sections improving Firing Line. Things going well.
Entry.211: Germans shelled Fleur Baix today doing considerable damage. Destroyed old Cathedral said to be 300 yrs. old.
Entry.212: Had charge parties revetting Bay Avenue. Wiring Duck Walks, etc. Things quiet.
Entry.213: All kinds of work in hand. News of big Russian successes. Things quiet here.
Entry.214: Things as usual. Heavy bombardment in places along our line, also of Enemy positions.
Entry.215: Some heavy Artillery actions on both sides. Aereal activity also. Things going well.
Entry.216: In charge parties revetting Avenues, etc. Also setting out new dugouts. Heavy shelling on Jay Post. Things going well.
Entry.217: Three Saprs. wounded today, Brice, Alta & Brown. Revetting trenches – putting in Dugouts, etc. Things going well.
Entry.218: Things rather quiet. A fair amount of shelling on both side. Enemy brought down one of our aeroplanes, no serious damage.
Entry.219: Shells lobbed in the village this afternoon killing Sap. McDonald, & two Infantrymen also wounding some. Usual work revetting & constructing & generally .
Entry.220: Charge parties Revetting trenches, cleaning out, building concrete shelters. Things going well. One or two casualties each day.
Entry.221: Same work as yesterday. Sap. Smith wounded last night by M. Gun bullets supposed mortally. Things as usual.
Entry.222: Heavy shelling by enemy of positions at Fleur Baix. Several casualties reported. Progressive work as usual. Nothing importance reported.
Entry.223: Work going on as usual, everything O.K. A good deal of Artillery fire from both side.
Entry.224: Cpl. Griggs wounded slightly, Sap. Gustephson more seriously being badly wounded in both legs, right shoulder & hand.
Entry.225: Usual work, revetting, Dugouts & general improvements. Things going well.
Entry.226: Cpl. Davidson & two saprs. wounded last night – one seriously. Things going well. Heavy bombardment by both sides last night not much damage.
Entry.227: Revetting work Avenues & doing other improvement work. Nothing fresh.
Entry.228: Usual work revetting & strengthening going on. Nothing of importance to report in our Sector.
Entry.229: Things going well, much work in hand strengthening positions.
Entry.230: Same work as usual. Strengthening positions, building concrete & splinter proof Dugouts.
Entry.231: Very heavy shower making work very difficult.
Entry.232: Still very showery. Working Dugouts & all kinds improvements.
Entry.233: Working Dugouts & revetting Avenues & making trenches generally fit for re-enter.
Entry.234: Very showery but clearing up. No working parties from Infantry, consequently work slack. (Visited Armentieres.)
Entry.235: A few working parties, only General work in revetting of all kinds, building dugouts, etc.
Entry.236: Same as usual. General improvement work, revetting, etc.
Entry.237: Fairly heavy Artillery duels. Much aerial activity & anti aircraft firing.
Entry.238: Usual work revetting & strengthening positions. Germans consentrated heavy fire on one Batter. Said to have knocked it out.
Entry.240: A quiet day – only a little bombardment on each side. Usual work strengthening positions.
Entry.241: Heavy Artillery Bombardment of enemy line. Eighth Brigade made a Raid at night. No success. One casualty.
Entry.242: Very heavy rain. Usual work on Dugouts & generally strengthening positions. Rain impairing work.
Entry.243: Nothing unusual. Fair amount of Artillery Fire on both side.
Entry.244: Still on Revetting work & strengthening positions generally. Nothing unusual.
Entry.245: Uneventful, a few Bombs thrown from both sides.
Entry.246: General bombardment on both side. Usual revetting & strengthening work.
Entry.247: Large Aerial Fleet fleeting to be seen over Enemy position. Said to have bombarded Line near Lille.
Entry.248: A good deal of Artillery preparation on both side. Work going on as usual. Showery droopy weather.
Entry.249: Very heavy showers making work very difficult. Fairly heavy bombardment both sides.
Entry.250: Still very showery. Continuing work revetting & strengthening generally. Fairly heavy Artillery Firing.
Entry.251: Heavy bombardment by our Artillery & trench Howitzers. Fairly heavy retaliation by Enemy Guns.
Entry.252: Short heavy bombardment by our Guns about 5 p.m. Nice fine day. Work as usual strengthening.
Entry.253: Usual Artillery activity & stokes Howitzers. Still revetting & strengthening.
Entry.254: Work going on as usually. Generally strengthening position, revetting & so on.
Entry.255: Things going well. Good work being done by Artillery & stokes Guns.
Entry.256: No alterations in position. Usual Artillery preparation.
Entry.257: Still working on revetting & other strengthening work including Concrete D.outs.
Entry.258: Work going on as usual. Still work on concrete Dugouts, etc.
Entry.259: Went to Gas School today & had very instructive lecture & course.
Entry.260: Working as usual revetting Avenues, etc.
Entry.261: Had quiet day. Fair amount of Artillery bombardment work same as usual.
Entry.262: Had very wet day causing most work to be abandoned. Still raining.
Entry.263: Still very wet making work progress very slow.
Entry.264: Weather taking up but still very sloppy. Working on revetting drainage, etc.
Entry.265: Working on revetting concrete Dugouts, drainage & other work improving position generally.
Entry.266: Beautiful fine day. Usual work strengthening position. Much aerial activity.
Entry.267: A good deal of Artillery activity. Very little response from Fritz.
Entry.268: Very busy all day. Usual revetting, Concrete Dugouts, etc. Bac St. Maur in Evening.
Entry.269: Working going as usual. Went B.R.E. yard in evening to get anchor of a new pattern made own design.
Entry.270: Nothing out of ordinary going. Fair amount of Artillery fire.
Entry.271: Usual work revetting & otherwise strengthening position, building concrete Dugouts, etc.
Entry.272: Wet weather again making work difficult. Nothing of importance going.
Entry.273: Usual work revetting Avenues & otherwise strengthening position. Fine weather again.
Entry.274: Nothing fresh going. Still revetting, etc.
Entry.275: Quiet day – usual work strengthening positions. Nothing of importance reported.
Entry.276: Usual stokes & artillery bombardment. Nothing else of importance.
Entry.277: Usual work revetting & building Concrete Dugouts.
Entry.278: Things going same as usual. Revetting etc. A good deal of Artillery preparation.
Entry.279: Revetting etc. as usual. Nothing fresh going. Visited tommies lines.
Entry.280: Fairly heavy bombardment by our Artillery & Trench Mortars.
Entry.281: Usual work revetting etc. Nothing fresh of importance to note.
Entry.282: Had fairly quiet day. Usual work strengthening position.
Entry.283: Wet weather retarding work, things going well.
Entry.284: A good deal Artillery activity. Nothing fresh of importance.
Entry.285:
Expect to move very soon. 
Finished up work in Trenches today.
Entry.286: Finished up in Trenches today. Expect to move tomorrow for "Somme".
Entry.287: Nos. 1 & 4 Sec. left as advance Guard to go as far as "Bac St. Maur". Nos. 2 & 3 to leave tomorrow. "Somme"!
Entry.288: Coy. arrived at Vieux Berquinat about 8 p.m. Marched about 2 miles to Billet.
Entry.289: Drilling & other kinds of training all day. Went to Vieux Berquinat - a small village.
Entry.290: Coy. training during morning. Played football afternoon. Vieux Berquinat at night.
Entry.291: Left Vieux Berquinat 6.15 p.m. Marched to Bailieul west & entrained. Left here 11 p.m. Wet weather.
Entry.292: Arrived "Pont Remy" about 11 a.m. Unloaded transport & marched about 4 miles to Billet at Francieres.
Entry.293: Transport left at 6 a.m. Had look at old Church built 1713. Still in state good preservation. Heavy rain.
Entry.294: Travelled all day per foot and motor & reached small village near Albert and camped for night.
Entry.295: Left billet early & marched through Albert – much knocked about & reached bivouac on high ridges near High Wood.
Entry.296: Waiting about camp all day. Heavy frost & very cold all day.
Entry.297: Working about camp – heavy rain & very cold. Terribly muddy.
Entry.298: Marched to High Wood & carried sand bags forward. 4 men killed, 3 wounded.
Entry.299: No. 2 & 4 took up camp near "High Wood". 1 man killed No. 3. Heavy shelling.
Entry.300: Heavy shelling both sides. Sapr. Rickard killed. No. 2 pushing stores forward. Very cold & wet. Things going well.
Entry.301: Nos. 1 & 2 work & pushing stores forward. Very wet, cold & muddy. Working at high pressure. No. 1 & 4 out at trenches. Expect to attack shortly.
Entry.302: Putting stores up to front line, also other fatigues. No. 1 & 4 at Trenches.
Entry.303: No. 2 proceed to trenches & took over from No. 1 & 4. Working in trenches during afternoon & all night – very muddy & wet.
Entry.304: Trenches again during afternoon & night. Heavy rain, trenches waist deep in mud & water. Men very exhausted.
Entry.305: Still very wet & muddy. Cleared up at night. Digging trenches with large Infantry party during night. Feel very exhausted.
Entry.306: Relieved by No. 3 Sec. & proceeded back to H.Q. Expecting to attack any time. Still wet & muddy. Large waste of men.
Entry.307: Resting today. Very tired after strenuous times in trenches. Still wet & muddy.
Entry.308: Nos. 1 & 2 Sec. were out at "Crest Trench" forming road. Usual bombardment going on. Still showery & muddy.
Entry.309: Excepting few fatigues, all resting. Expect to attack in front Bapaume tomorrow. Tommies attack as "Left".
Entry.310: 7th Brigade A.I.F. made attack in front Bapaume & Tommies on left. Only partial success.
Entry.311: Coy. withdrew today from Front Line. Resting – everybody exhausted. Still wet & very muddy everywhere.
Entry.312: Packing & loading carts. Expect to leave today or tomorrow. Very miserable weather. Had two Saprs. killed. 5 Infantry in trenches last night.
Entry.313: Left camp 3.30 a.m., marched 12 miles to Redemont . Left here 1.30 p.m. marched 2 miles & took Motors to "Cardonette", 5 miles from "Amiens".
Entry.314: Resting today. Many of men in Coy. sick & exhausted. Nice weather. 56th Batt. Billetted here.
Entry.315: Had two hours Parade & Drill in morning. Resting in afternoon. Nice weather! Expect leave tomorrow for London.
Entry.316: Been waiting all day for Pass to go on leave to London. Very cloudy, a little rain. Nothing important.
Entry.317: Left for London on leave. Went to Bertangles & found it was wrong station. Went to "Amiens" at Saint Roch. Took train to Boulogne.
Entry.318:
Arrived 
Rouen
 Boulogne about midnight last night 
about
 after a tiring journey. Stayed Rest Camp.
Entry.319: Arrived London about 11 a.m. and took room Union Jack Club. Very bad with influenza.
Entry.320: Still bad with flue, cannot get about to see anything. Only been about a little.
Entry.321: Had a fair look around City. In evening went to Leytonstone & stayed night with Mrs. Mr. Smith. Nice people.
Entry.322: Still got very bad cold. Staying with same people but not feeling fit to go to City. Looked around Leytonstone.
Entry.323: Had a run to the City but everything was to wet & miserable. Had a look at good show at Stratford at night.
Entry.324: Very wet, cold & miserable. Was out very little. Had a look round in morning & went to Stratford at night.
Entry.325: Left Leytonstone about noon & went to City. At night Mr. & Mrs. Smith and I went to "Palladium". Good show.
Entry.326: Had look City today. Did not get anything of importance. Did some business.
Entry.327: Went to City in afternoon & had a look over Tower London. With Smith to show Stratford night.
Entry.328: Left Leytonstone in afternoon & missed troop train at Waterloo. Went to Royal at night & saw "Best of Luck".
Entry.329: Left Leytonstone & caught troop train in afternoon. Left Southhampton about 9 p.m. for France.
Entry.330: Disembarked Havre about 7 a.m. & went to Rest Camp. Left for Rouen about 11 p.m.
Entry.331: Arrived Rouen about 7 a.m. & went to Rest Camp. Left for "Front" about 4 p.m. Travelling all night. Much delay. Frosty.
Entry.332: Left Rouen Camp about 1.30 p.m. and arrived in Albert about 7 p.m. Very slow journey. Much delayed.
Entry.333: Stayed in Albert all day with Capt. Chappel & Capt. McNab. They left for Front about 10 p.m. I stayed Albert.
Entry.334: Left Albert about 9.30 a.m. for Front with Lt. Morgan 15th Trench Mortars. Reached Coy. H.Q. about 2 p.m.
Entry.335: Taking things easy as I still have bad cold & I do not want to get worse one. Waterloo Farm.
Entry.336: Went to Trenches today & had a look around. Sec. working in various places.
Entry.337: Working Needle Trench also Deep Dugouts & laying Duck walk track.
Entry.338: Repairing Needle Trench Deep Dugouts & laying Duck walk tracks. Very cold – Ice everywhere.
Entry.339: Same routine as yesterday. Fine clear day. Enemy aeroplane brought down.
Entry.340: Building Dugouts and doing other improvements in lines. Heavy Artillery fire by Enemy. Warmer.
Entry.341: Usual fog, freezing, very hard laying Duck walk track & general improvements.
Entry.342: Same as usual repairing trenches, laying tracks, etc. Very cold.
Entry.343: Ice everywhere, ground frozen hard, still doing repairing in trenches, etc.
Entry.344: Heavy fogs & freezing hard. Same work as usual.
Entry.345: Usual work in trenches. Still very cold. Heavy misty weather. Lots of shelling both sides.
Entry.346: Bright this morning. Aeroplanes very busy. Saw two enemy planes brought down.
Entry.347: Cloudy again today, heavy artillery fire on both side. Fritz very busy.
Entry.348: Usual work in trenches. Activity both sides artillery. Fritz very busy – mostly shelling old villages.
Entry.349: Heavy hostile shelling with fairly heavy casualty list. Usual trench work. Fairly fine weather.
Entry.350: Heavy hostile shelling, a good many casualties. Carrying on work as usual in trenches, etc.
Entry.351: Fine in morning, raining, snow in afternoon – fairly quiet.
Entry.352: Rather quiet today. Very heavy fog in afternoon & very cold. Usual improvement work.
Entry.353: A good deal of Artillery fire on both side. Very cold. Usual improvements.
Entry.354: Same work as usual. Revetting trenches & generally consolidating position.
Entry.355: Freezing very hard, very very cold with a little snow. Nothing unusual.
Entry.356: A little rain, very muddy again – cold. A good deal Artillery fire.
Entry.357: Not much work today. A fair amount Artillery fire both side.
Entry.358: Move back about a mile to a new Camp. Handed over to 5th F Coy.
Entry.359: Started build huts "Nissen Bow" on new site for camp. Things quiet.
Entry.360: Not much doing today – a very quiet Xmas & not too much to eat. Visited 1st F Coy. Engrs.
Entry.361: Working on new camp. Heavy fog, very cold & light rain. A little shelling.
Entry.362: New job supervising road formation on Road – Montauban Quarry Siding Bazentine.
Entry.363:
Working going well on road & Railway Siding. Things quiet. Very little shelling.

Friday 19 December 1916
Entry.364: routine as yesterday forming roads & working at Siding.
Entry.365: Nothing fresh going. Conferences still discussing peace.
Entry.366: Uneventful day. Working on Road Construction. Fair amount shelling going on. Wet as usual.
Entry.367: Plenty of work going on – roads going well. Heavy shelling last night.
Entry.368: Same as yesterday. Uneventful day. Fair amount shelling. Overcast & misty.
Entry.369: Still working on Corpl. work – plenty of work & things going well. Uneventful.
Entry.370: Wet weather nothing fresh going. Plenty of work going ahead on Roads.
Entry.371: Same work supervising Roads & drainage. Cold & damp.
Entry.372:
Nothing fresh. A good deal of shelling going on.

F. C.

To come from S.M. – 4.25

Loan to Cpl. Carlyle Fcs. – 5

T Sgt. Ogilvy Frcs. 15
Entry.373: Still on Road Supervising. Cold & wet. Things going well. Nothing fresh going.
Entry.374: Things going well on Road work. A good deal of shelling going on.
Entry.375: Transferred from 14th F.C. Engrs. to 1st Anzac Light Railway Operation Corps.
Entry.376: Took up duty with C.L.R. Things very much mixed up at present. Expect to go better before long.
Entry.377: Been having a very strenuous time. Things are very much mixed up owing to overlapping of the old & new formations.
Entry.378: Things are not working at all smoothly. Having a rough time trying to cope with work.
Entry.379: Still doing plenty of work trying to get things going on the Railway work.
Entry.380: Still acting S.Maj. getting plenty to do and things not too satisfactory. Expect to leave it.
Entry.381: Saw the Colonel today & intend leaving today.
Entry.382: Left A.C.L.R. last night & came back to the old Coy. Taking No. 2 Sec.
Entry.383: Snow set in last night & continued to fall lightly all day. Very cold.
Entry.384: Half the Coy. – No. 1 & 2 Secs. shifted camp in 8th F. Coy’s Camp & took over their work. I took over C.R.E. defence work. Still snowing.
Entry.385: Working on C.R. Defences. Cold & freezing. A fair amount of shelling.
Entry.386: Same as yesterday. Very cold but fine.
Entry.387: Heavy shelling – large shells falling close to our work. Cold but fine.
Entry.388: Still working on C.R.E. defences. Weather very cold. A good deal Artillery fire on both side.
Entry.389: C.R.E. defence work. Intensely cold. Aerial activity and a good deal of Artillery both side.
Entry.390: Same work as yesterday. Still very cold but fine. Heavy shelling.
Entry.391: C.R.E. defences. One of Fritz’s aeroplanes brought down near where we are working.
Entry.392: 3 more of Fritzes Planes brought down. Heavy shelling both sides.
Entry.393: 3 more of Fritzes Planes brought down within sight. 29th Div. hopped over last night & took some trenches & about 300 prisoners.
Entry.394: Still very cold. Heavy shelling both side.
Entry.395: Still very cold. Heavy snow lying on the ground, everything frozen. Fairly lively artillery from both sides.
Entry.396: Still working on C.R.E. Defences. Very cold.
Entry.397: C.R.E. Defences. Still bitterly cold. Heavy artillery activity on both sides.
Entry.398: 4th Div. hopped over at night & took some of Jerry’s trenches but were compelled to evacuate them early next morning. Took about 40 prisoners. We lost fairly heavily.
Entry.399: Heavy German shelling during the early morning Still very cold.
Entry.400: Still on C.R.E. defences. Very heavy shelling by our Guns today.
Entry.401: Same work on C.R.E. Defences. Nothing of importance going.
Entry.402: Still having cold weather. Same old shelling.
Entry.403: C.R.E. Defence work. Nothing fresh going.
Entry.404: Nothing fresh going. Artillery active. C.R.E. Defence work.
Entry.405: Having cold weather still. C.R.E. Defence work.
Entry.406: Heavy shelling both side. C.R.E. Defences. Nothing fresh doing.
Entry.407: Having a series of Lectures by O.C. Still cold. Artillery activity.
Entry.408: Still on Deep dugouts. Fairly lively shelling both sides.
Entry.409: Still on O.C.’s Lectures. Nothing fresh going.
Entry.410: Artillery activity brisk both sides. Cold. Still on C.R.E. Defences.
Entry.411: Still working on Deep dugouts. Brisk shelling both sides.
Entry.412: Nothing fresh going. Still on C.R.E. Defence work.
Entry.413: Large amunition Dump blown up this morning by "Taub" continued to burn & shells to explode all day.
Entry.414: Big Dump still burning & shells exploding. Said to have been £2,000,000 lost.
Entry.415: Weather getting warmer & wet weather set in. Still on C.R.E. Defences. British Success on the Ancre.
Entry.416: Very wet & ground getting very muddy. Heavy artillery fire.
Entry.417: Still on C.R.E. D. Very foggy weather and wet.
Entry.418: Finer weather. Fair amount of shelling from Jerry. Still on C.R.E. Defences at Ginchy and 2nd Line.
Entry.419: Nothing fresh to report. Things going well.
Entry.420: Hand over C.R.E. Defences to 8th & 15th Field Coys. Look over work from other Sections.
Entry.421: Working on various jobs Delville Wood, Montauban, etc.
Entry.422: 3 Sections has gone to camp at Fleurs. No. 2 Section is doing back work.
Entry.423: Still on back works. Germans are said to be retiring to new Lines.
Entry.424: Still on back works. Nothing fresh going.
Entry.425: Still working on hutting & other back line work.
Entry.427: Good advances are being made along our front in small Sectors.
Entry.428: Still doing good work all along the Line. Germans falling back it is thought to Cambrai.
Entry.429: Still carrying out work about "Bernafoy", "Longueval", "Delville Wood", etc. Still good news along Front.
Entry.430:
"Bavarian Foot Guards" attack 1st Div. last night near Thilloy & were badly beaten nearly a whole Coy taken prisoners beside many being 
taken
 killed & wounded.
Entry.431: Nothing fresh going. Still working on Hutting, etc.
Entry.432: Things going well along Front. Still working on Hutting & general improvement behind the Lines.
Entry.433: Joined Coy. at Bulls Run near Guidecourt.
Entry.434: Section doing work on Brde. H.Q. near Fleurs & Guedecourt also Guedecourt also putting in M.G. positions & doing work on Coy. H.Q.
Entry.435: Left for Becordel for eye treatment & arrived about 10 p.m.
Entry.436:
Find I will have to wait for a week for treatment owing to a large number of patients waiting. Went to 
Belb
 Bellevue Farm & saw Reg Monaghan.
Entry.437: Had a stroll into Albert. Paid a visit to Y.M.C.A. & stayed for Service at night.
Entry.438: Met Charlie Monaghan & had a talk to Reg. Still waiting for eye treatment.
Entry.439: Went to see Reg Monaghan at night. Charlie M. also came. Good news of advancement in Front.
Entry.440: Have made mistake in dates, all should be one day ahead. Missed a day somewhere.
Entry.441: A cold day. Still waiting at C.C.S. for eye treatment. Charlie Monaghan, Reg & I went to see a Show in Albert at night run by an Australian Troupe. Very good.
Entry.442: Did not go to Amiens for eye test after all. Got discharge from Becordel & rejoined Unit at Guidecourt. Expect to move forward tomorrow.
Entry.443: 15th Div. moved fordward of the German Lines on the ridge at Bapaume today. Nos. 2 & 3 Sections, Capt. Carr in charge, were attached to the 59th Battn. We moved right forward with very little resistance as far as Fremicourt & were held up at a point about 1 mile forward of this village and after about 2 hrs. skirmishing this position was taken with few casualties. Beugny was entered late in evening & a little resistance met with – patrols going in at night but it was abandoned & will be enveloped tomorrow. The Huns have destroyed everything possible in there retreat – Churches, houses & deep Dugouts have been mined and destroyed. Fruit trees cut down & long avenues of trees destroyed along the Main Rd. Much wilful destruction has been carried on in all the villages.
Entry.444: We got out (No. 2 Sec.) at daylight & commenced operations filling in Mine Craters along the
Entry.445: Roads between Fremicourt & Beugny & returned again at night to Fremicourt & Bivouaced for night. Good progress was made during the day altho’ strong opposition was met on both flanks. Beugny is now strongly held by us.
Entry.446: We got out early again this morning & started work again on the Rds. & water supply. We camped this evening in the Lebucquiere & at night our Sec. was out digging strong points & M.G. positions. We are now holding a position in front of Bometz.
Entry.447:
Busily engaged on well sinking today & at 
half
 night half the Sec. was engaged digging strong points in front of Bometz.
Entry.448:
Engaged in Well digging today. Things rather quiet with the Inf. but Fritz shelled the Village Lebucquiere rather heavily & put a lot of shrapnel on our left.

23rd

At daybreak Fritz made a heavy attack on Bometz & the high country on our Left. He got possession of the Village but was driven back as he was in all positions with heavy loss but our casualties were fairly heavy also. Capt. Booth was killed & also another
Entry.449: Officer whos name I do not know. During the attack Fritz kept heavy shelling with H.E. explosives both shrapnel & percussion. We held the position with very few men.
Entry.450:
Batt. held Bometz & 30th in support. Good support is coming in today. Major McArthur has given our Secn. high praise for the support we gave the Inf. this morning.

24th

Further fighting has been carried on amongst the outposts. A good deal of shelling going on on both side.
Entry.451:
Fritz made another attack on the left flank of Beaumetz this morning. We repulsed him but had fairly heavy losses. This afternoon the 59th Batt. made an attack on our 
our
 Right flank doing fine work running Fritz out of his position & occupying a sunken Rd. near Beaumetz. We suffered fairly heavy losses from shell, shrapnel and M.G. bullets.

26th

Did some reconnaisance work for water at Velu where some beautiful old Chateaux have been mined & layed in ruins. This morning 2nd Div. attacked & captured Lagnicourt on our left. Fritz attack four times during the day to try & regain it
Entry.452: but we still hold it. Heavy shelling by evening, guns nearly all day.
Entry.453: Things going well everywhere. Small skirmishes only reported. Still on Well sinking.
Entry.454: A good deal of shelling from Fritz today. Nothing of great importance reported. Still Well sinking.
Entry.455: Good news continues to come in from most of the Fronts. Small local skirmishes only. Very heavy bombardment heard north where it is believed a heavy offensive has been started by the British.
Entry.456: Still Well sinking. Nothing importance reported, only a little shelling on both sides. Cpl. Morrison & I visited Beaumetz to look for water, no luck.
Entry.457: Engaged Well sinking & clearing old well out. Nothing of importance going.
Entry.458:
Engaged well sinking & at night we demolished an old obelisk near Beaumetz. It was about 70’ high and 7’ diam. at base & it is thought that the Enemy were using it as a Ranging mark. 
Early this
Entry.459: Early this morning the 56th & 58th Batt. advanced about 2000 yds. & captured Louverval & Boignies. Our casualties were fairly heavy. During the day Enemy shelling was very heavy on our new positions & he counter attacked 3 times on Boignies but without success.
Entry.460:
Today Sapr. Smith A.E.W. & I visited Louverval & Doignies to look for Wells, found one Well at Boignies which appears to have good water in it. All the rest have either been mined or filled with rubbish. There was heavy Enemy shelling in both villages while we were there. At about 6.30 p.m. one of Fritz’s aeroplanes shot down two of Balloons which fell in flames. The aeroplane got back safely to his lines.

4th

Heavy bombardment is on left where a big move has been commenced. Nothing of importance on our Front.
Entry.461:
Still Well sinking & have a good flow of water. Struck water at 77’.

5th

Went to Doignies today & fixed 
wa
 windlass on a Well. Also withdrew two German mines from under a house. Handing over work here tomorrow to 3rd F.C. Engrs.
Entry.463:
Left Lebecquiere in morning & march to Baupaum & camped about ½ mile from town. Very windy and cold.

7th

H.Q. & Nos. 1 & 4 Secs. joined us today. Employed gathering timber in Bapaum and building Stables.

8th

No. 2 Sec. employed filling in large crater & doing other road repairs. Good work reported from Front.

To Kodaks P.T.

Seven films 66.5

H. Eddingshausen

Bong Bong St.

Kiama, N.S.W.

Mrs. Saindy

Miller St.

Haberfield

N.S.W.

G.L. Lekegian & Coy., Studio opposite Shepheards Hotel

Langdon, Carey St.

Waverly

Aerodrome Camp

Heliopolis via Cairo

Lette

Murray St.

No. 2493

Joy Patterson, Woodburn R. River

Annie Lette, Langford, 7 Carey St., Waverly

Clarice Myers," Kalimud "Ballan Victoria

W. Bourke, 236 Mitchell Road, Alexandria

C. Monaghan, No. 9371-15 Re. Inf., 1st F.A.M.

Dart, Occidental Avenue, A Box Cobar P.O.

W. Bourke, 13 Lyrie St., Alexandria

Norton, 355 New Canterbury Rd., Dulwich Hill.

H. Smith, Mabel House, 82 Wood House Rd., Leytonstone, London, N.E.

Mrs. Friel, 55 Kelvinside Ave., Glasgow, Scotland.

Mr. G. Smith, Overseer, Postmans Office, East Central Section, King Edwards Bdg., General P.O., E.C.

Mr. H. Smith, "Mabel House", 82 Woodhouse Rd., Leytonstone, London , E.C.

Mrs Carlyle, 1 Peter St. off Corporation Rd., Carlisle

Sgt. Richardson, No. 3 Command Depot, A.I.F., Convalescent Camp, Bovington Wood, Dorset Wood

G. Murray, Wardell, Richmond.

H. Murray, Lt. 2493, 5th F. Coy. Engrs., 2nd Division

J. Murray, No. 3 General Hospital, Wandsworth.

Miss W.M. Rissey, 19 Canarvon Crescent, Boscombe.

Mrs. E. Nicholls, 79 Davis St., Subiaco, W.A.

Mrs. E. Brown, Second Alexandria Rd., Glebe

Miss C. Johnston, The Bungalow, Redan St., Mosman

(Sup. Roberts)

110 Sgt. J.C. Watterson, 6 Donnington Rd., Reading, England.

E & C Mayo, Newbyrie, Roseville Av., Roseville, Sydney.

Dr. Thomas, Mt. Pleasant

Matthews, Stan, Miller Rd., Belfast.

M. Monaghan, 42 Bruce St., Stanmore

C. Monaghan, No. 2 A.G.H., Boulogne, France

Murray, H., No. 9 Ward, No. 9 Gen. Hospital, Rouen

Localities souvenirs sent home.

No. 1 "Doignies"

No. 2 "Lebecquiere"

No. 3 Beaumetz

No. 4 Fremicourt
Entry.464:
After much preparation including heavy bombardment by our Artillery the 5th Division at about 6 p.m. went over the parapet & attacked Enemy position. Not much resistance was met with where our Brigade went over although our casualties were fairly heavy. The 53rd & 54th Batt. were the attacking Battalions, supported by 55th & 56th. Our troops charged magnificiently clearly the enemy from their front Line & following up their advantage charged to the second line of Defense about 800 yards beyond & here again ran the enemy out of his Trench & took possession. Here however we came under our own Artillery curtain fire & had to fall back to about four hundred yards of the enemy first line of Defense & here we dug in & consolidated during the night. At daylight on the morning of 20th we found 
that
 that we were in an isolated position being about 400 yds. in advance of enemy first line & having no support on our right & left flanks. At this juncture the enemy bombed along the trench – the firing line that we had taken the afternoon previously closing in from the right Flank & worked his way in behind the 53rd Batt. who then began to retire followed shortly afterward by the 54th with some of the 55th in support of each Batt. Swinging slightly to our Left Flank we retired across the German Front Line across "No Mans land" & back to our own Line,

bombing parties in the meantime did splendid work holding the enemy in check while the remainder of the Batt. got back to our own lines. During the night splendid work was done by the fatigue parties especially those under the supervision of our Company, the Company coming in for high praise for the work done. No. 2 Section was chosen to go over in the charge in the
Entry.465: wave - Sgt. Richardson in charge of one party & I in charge of another. Of Sgt. Richardson’s party l.Cpl. Atkinson, Sapr. Johnstone, Norton.
Entry.466: No. 2 Section again on road repairs at Grevillers. Very bad weather. Still doing well on all Fronts.
Entry.467: No. 2 Sec. engaged building huts for Coy. Good news through of big advance by British near Arras, 10,000 prisoners taken & about 100 Guns includ. 8" & 4.9 Guns.
Entry.468: Still good news from British Front where the big advance started on the 9th. Still working on Rds.
Entry.469:
Still working on Rds. It is now said that British near Arras have captured 200 Guns.

13th

Still working about Bapaum. 1st & 4th Divs. got a rough handling this morning near Hernicourt but eventually turned defeat into victory on being reinforced by the
Entry.471: Still on roads etc. about Bapaum. On our Front yesterday the Hun captured 16 of our 18 destroying 2 of them but they were all recaptured.
Entry.472:
It is now reported that the British have captured 14,000 prisoners & 
194,000
 194 guns.
Entry.473: In the engagement on our Front we captured 300 prisoners & it is estimated that at least 1500 of the enemy were killed.
Entry.474: Big French success in the Champagne district on 25 mile Front. Things still going well on the whole British Front.
Entry.475: Section pegging out position for Defences round Bievilliers. Very cold windy wet weather.
Entry.476: Sec. standing by today. Expect to leave early in morning for unknown destination. Reported French have captured 19,000 prisoners and 90 guns.
Entry.477: No. 2 Section marched out of camp & proceeded to "Bazentin" followed later by the whole company and camped for the night. Nice fine weather.
Entry.478: Marched to Becourt & took up camp there. Expect to leave here soon.
Entry.479: Nice fine day. Went into Albert with Sgts. Banks & Barnes. A few civilians coming back. Saw Reg. Monaghan. Still good news coming in from all allied Fronts.
Entry.484: Just a little Coy. Fatigues & Drilling.
Entry.485: Went to Albert & saw a Picture Show, wasn’t too bad. Nothing fresh going to report.
Entry.486: Still out resting. Nothing fresh of importance to note.
Entry.489: Nothing fresh going. Having beautiful weather.
Entry.490: Still having lovely weather. Sections doing Pontooning & fatigues.
Entry.492: Div. Sports today. Horses were looking beautiful & turnover was very good.
Entry.493: Church Parade this morning. Coy. played 55th Soccer in afternoon & won.
Entry.495:
Too wet for training. Getting ready for entraining.

9th

Left Becourt 
for
 and per foot & train travelled to Vaulx & relieved 7th F. Coy. Engrs. Lively Artillery firing along Line.
Entry.496: Very heavy Artillery firing along this Front. Enemy firing a lot of shells on positions right back here.
Entry.497: Coy. doing a little training & a little Front line work. 12th, 15th Brigade & a Tommy Brigade hopped over.
Entry.498:
Party from my Sec. out wiring tonight in Front of Line. Very heavy bombardment by our Guns. Expect hop over in morning

18th
Entry.499: this morning & took some trenches & Bullecourt & are holding position. 15th took 170 odd prisoners & altogether about 300 were taken. Casualties were rather high & Fritz supposed to have suffered heavily. Visited Ecourt & Noreuil today – what is left of them? Came to sunken Rd. near Noreuil in evening to work on deep dugouts.
Entry.500: My party continued to work on Deep Dugouts till 6 oclock this afternoon & then returned to camp. A lot of shelling by both sides.
Entry.501: Came back to Bug St. this afternoon with 17 men to continue work on Dugouts. About 9 p.m. Jerry started to throw Gas shells over making things very unpleasant.
Entry.502: Still working on Deep dugouts. The shelling last night was very heavy & our casualties in the Front line heavy too. Fritz attacked & a few of his men got into a portion of our trench but he was repulsed with very heavy loss. The gas attack last night with shells was the longest on record lasting continuously for 5 hrs. & about 9 hours intermittantly. It was mostly Tear stuff but at times carried "K stuff".
Entry.503: Things were quiet this morning but fairly lively in the afternoon. Raining.
Entry.504: A good deal of Artillery work on both side. Nothing fresh going. It is thought that the enemy has gone further back on our Front. Still employed on Deep dugout work near "Noreuil".
Entry.505: Things rather quiet on our Front. A good shells came over last night, a fair amount with Gas. Weather clearing up.
Entry.506: Unusually heavy Artillery bombardments. Still on Deep dugout at Bug St. near Noreuil.
Entry.507: Nothing fresh to report. Heavy Artillery work as usual. Working on Deep dugouts.
Entry.508: Left Bug St. this morning with Sec. Office "M. Brigdon" & 15 other ranks to put wire out at Front Line. Was caught in Heavy Barage while waiting in Supports but had no casualties.
Entry.509: Had rough but successful night last night, got large carrying Party right to the Front Line near Reincourt with wire & "Corkscrews" and did a fair amount of wiring in front of Lines. The Enemy discovered us about 2 a.m. & suddenly opened a heavy Barage fire on us & we had to leave in a hurry. Had very wet & dark night for work.
Entry.510: Sec. mostly resting & doing a little camp work etc. Nothing. No. 1 & 3 wiring.
Entry.511: Nice fine weather. Things quiet. In the afternoon I took one of the 68th R.E. Officers out to the Front Line. They are taking over from us.
Entry.512: Left Vaulx today & came to a camp near Fremicourt.
Entry.513: Still near Fremicourt. Having a rest. Nice fine weather.
Entry.514: Nothing fresh to report on on this Front. Big success on Italian Fronts.
Entry.515: Still having nice fine weather. Nothing fresh doing.
Entry.516: Coy. played 20th Div. Gloucesters A.S.C. Rugby League & won 3 to nil. Rough game. 3 of Gloucesters had to leave field.
Entry.517: Sec. digging trenches near Villa de Flos. Other Secs. doing the same.
Entry.518:
Still on "Strong points". Doing a little training.

1st
Entry.520: Training & diging trenches but having easy time.
Entry.522: Nothing fresh going. Having easy time.
Entry.523: No. 2 Sec. played No. 3 & won with two wickets. Nothing fresh.
Entry.524: Coy. had route march today about 5 miles. Played
Entry.526: Working on Sports ground & doing camp work & a little training. Played a Tommy A.S.C. & won easily.
Entry.527: Had Div. sports today & 14th F. Coy. came out on top with 47 points to 15th Coys. 36. 8th F. got 23 & Sigs. 22, got Silver Cup.
Entry.528:
A little squad drill & Coy. Fatigues. Nothing of importance to note.

11th

Good news from North British – including our 3rd &
Entry.529: Divs. & N. Zealanders advanced on a 9 mile front taking a lot of prisoners & a good many guns.
Entry.530: Still good news from Front North of Armentiers. All Enemy counter attacks beaten off. Lost Soccer to 15th yesterday.
Entry.531: Having general clean-up today preparatory to moving out.
Entry.532: Getting ready to move out tomorrow. Played
Entry.533: Rugby today & won 14 to 9. Some more ground won near Arras.
Entry.534: Handed over Camp today to 5th F. Coy. Engrs. & marched into Baupaume arriving there about 7 p.m. Took train to Warloy & marched from there to Milancourt.
Entry.535: Not too well today. Nothing much happened.
Entry.537: Marched 15 --- today & had swim. Having easy time.
Entry.538: Left Milancourt at 8 a.m. & marched to Corbie arriving about 11.30 a.m. Nothing doing during evening.
Entry.539: Company training on Pontoon Rafting on River Somme on outskirts Corbie. Everywhere roundabout Corbie is very beautiful & it is an important manufacturing center.
Entry.540: Coy. doing Pontooning on Somme. Nothing fresh to report.
Entry.541: Coy. still on same work. Off duty today. Not well.
Entry.544: Shifted Pontoons further down River where we have G.O.C. Inspection tomorrow.
Entry.545: Three Coys. put bridges across water today & were Inspected by G.O.C. Our Coy. built bridge 170’ in 15 min. & were fastest in time. Everything very satisfactory.
Entry.546: No bridging today. Went to Amiens with Sgt. Barnes & Cpl. Morrison. Amiens very busy. Good time.
Entry.547:
Coy. training for Div. sports 
a
 "Aquatic".
Entry.548: No bridging. Coy. training rowing & swimming for Div. Sports.
Entry.549: Still training on Bridges & training for Sports.
Entry.550: Shifting material further up the river and getting ready for sports.
Entry.552:
F. Coy. led in points although 8th, our Coy, did very well winning nearly all the swimming events.

4th

Dismantling gear after sports & taking material to new site for further bridging.
Entry.553: Trestle bridging, etc. Nothing fresh going.
Entry.554: Trestle bridge & general work on the Canal.
Entry.555: No. 2 Sec. erecting Pile Driver in River in morning. Coy. played 15th Coy. Aus. Rules football in afternoon & won 66-22 thus winning the Cup.
Entry.556: No Parades today except for Coy. fatigues. Heavy rain during last night but pleasant today.
Entry.557: Writing in Anzac House just close to Cathedral which I have just been having a look through for the 2nd time. On Leave today. Reached Corbie about 9 p.m. Amiens looking very lively.
Entry.559:
Pile Driving today on River Somme. Nice weather. Starting a new Diary from the 10th – one I bought in Amiens on the 9th.

This is a very scrappy Diary – written in all kinds of places and under all kinds of conditions. Some of the parts are written in pencil & are almost faded or rubbed out. You will notice that I have been trying to ink it over in some of these places. But although it is very scrappy & dirty & untidy I will be able to tell you lots of things with it to refresh my memory that I might not otherwise be able to think of. I hope it will reach home safely.

Love from Your EM
